Implications of the big bang

General relativity connects space and time as one entity called space-time.

Dark matter and dark energy

Dark matter Matter which cannot be seen and does not absorb or emit EM radiation . It cannot be directly observed but can be detected indirectly based on it’s gravitational effects relating to the rotation of galaxies, or by gravitational lensing of starlight

Dark energy A type of energy that permeates the whole universe and opposes the attractive force of gravitation between galaxies via the exertion of a negative pressure. It is not detected directly, but we know that is exists because we now know that the universe is accelerating as it expands

The fate of the universe is dependent on its density.

  • If the density is too large, it will collapse upon itself
  • If the density is too small, it will expand forever and cool
  • If the density is exactly equal to the critical density, it will expand and reach a final finite size in an infinite amount of time

Deriving the critical density of the universe

ρc=3H08πG≈9.5×10−27 kg m−3

This is equivalent to approximately equal to 5-6 hydrogen atoms per cubic metre. If this density is stable then the universe will neither expand or collapse.

Particles and medical physics

Capacitors

Capacitor A circuit component that stores energy by separating charges onto two electrical conductors with an insulator between them. One plate becomes positively charged and the other negatively charged

Capacitance C The capacitance of a capacitor is defined as the quantity of charge, Q, which can be stored per unit potential difference, V, across the plates of the capacitor

The unit of capacitance is the farad, F. The farad has units of C V−1

Charge separation on a capacitor

When a capacitor is connected to a source of e.m.f charge cannot flow between the plates of the capacitor.
Electrons will be transferred from the negative terminal onto one plate, which becomes negatively charged, and off the other plate, which becomes positively charged.
Once the capacitor has become fully charged, no more charge will flow in the circuit since the electrons on the negatively charged plate will repel any further electrons away.
At this point the potential difference across the capacitor will be equal to the e.m.f of the cell.

Capacitance

A value of 1 F for a capacitor is extremely high, it is more likely that values will be in micro or pico farads.

Example

A capacitor has a capacitance of 47 μF. It is connected to a cell so that a potential difference of 12 V is across the plates of the capacitor.
Calculate the charge stored on the plates

Q=VC=12×47×10−6≈5.6×10−4 C

Investigation

Measuring capacitance

Although digital multimeters can be used to measure capacitance directly, we can also determine the capacitance of a capacitor from the values of charge against voltage.
The gradient of the linear fit of these values gives an accurate value of the capacitance.

Method of finding the charge

Set up a cell in series with a switch before it and a variable resistor and microammeter afterwards. Connect this in series with the capacitor with a high resistance voltmeter across it.
Once the switch is closed charge flows and the variable resistor can be used to keep the value of the current constant until the capacitor becomes fully charged.
Upon closing the switch, start a stopwatch and record values for the current and potential difference at regular intervals until the current falls to zero, showing that the capacitor is fully charged.
The charge can then be found by Q=It.

Connect a cell in series with a resistor. Across the resistor, connect the capacitor in series with either, determined by a switch, a voltmeter or coulombmeter.
Charge the capacitor to different voltages and measure the charge stored for each value.
Find the percentage difference between the nominal capacitance values and the experimental values.

Capacitors in series and parallel

Capacitors in parallel

Suppose that three capacitors are connected in parallel with one another.
A battery of potential difference v is then connected across them so that they each have potential difference V.
The total charge, Q, stored on the capacitors must be the sum of the charge stored on each of the capacitors, Q=Q1+Q2+Q3.
The charge Qn on each capacitor is found from CnV.
Since the potential difference across each of the three capacitors is the same, and equal to the potential difference V, we have

CV=C1V+C2V+C3V

or

C=C1+C2+C3

The total capacitance of a parallel network of capacitors is equal to the sum of the capacitance of the individual capacitors.

Example

Three capacitors of capacitance 47 μF, 90 μF, and 120 μF are connected in parallel to a 16 V battery. Calculate:

a) the total capacitance of the parallel arrangement
We use C=C1+C2+C3 giving C=257 μF

b) the total charge stored by the parallel network
For each capacitor, Q=VC, so the total charge is
16 V×(47+90+120) μF=4113 μC≈4.1 mC

Capacitors in series

Suppose that three capacitors are connected in series with one another and a cell.

Applying Kirchhoff’s second law to the circuit loop, the e.m.f of the cell will be equal to the sum of the potential differences across the individual capacitors in the circuit

V=V1+V2+V3

To find the charge present on each plate of the capacitors, consider the middle capacitor.
This is not actually connected to the battery.
As the plates are uncharged before connection to the battery, uncharged (in total) after connection.
Consider the two plates on adjacent capacitors and the write between them. The positively charged plate on the first capacitor will induce an equal but opposite negative charge on its other plate. The electrons that flow onto this plate must have come from the positive plate on the second capacitor, which will acquire a positive charge.
A similar situation is true on the plates of the second and third capacitors.
Hence, every plate has the same magnitude charge on it in a series circuit.

To determine the total capacitance of a series arrangement of capacitors, we use

V=V1+V2+V3 and V=QC

to obtain

QC=QC1+QC2+QC3

cancelling Q we have

1C=1C1+1C2+1C3

Example

Three capacitors of capacitance 20 μF, 40 μF, and 80 μF are connected in series to a cell of e.m.f 12 V.
Calculate:

a) the effective capacitance of the arrangement
1C=120+140+180
C=1120+140+180
C=807≈11.43 μF

b) the charge stored on the 20 μF capacitor
We use Q=VC where Q is the charged stored, V is the cell e.m.f, and C is the effective capacitance.
Q=12×807≈137.1 μC

c) the potential difference across the 20 μF capacitor
The potential difference across the 20 μF capacitor is given by V=QC.
V=137.1 μC20 μF≈6.9 V

Example

A circuit contains a 3 μF capacitor that has been connected in series to a parallel network that contains a 2 μF capacitor and a 4 μF capacitor. This is then connected to a cell of e.m.f 12 V.
Calculate:

a) the effective capacitance of the circuit
The two capacitors arranged in parallel have an effective capacitance of 2 μF+6 μF=6 μF. Considering the 3 μF capacitor in series with the parallel network we have
1C=13+16
which gives C=2 μF

b) the charge on each capacitor
For the whole circuit, Q=VC, leading to Q=12×2μ=24 μC
This means that there will be a charge of 24 μC on the 3 μF capacitor and a charge of 24 μC shared across the two capacitors arranged in paralle.
The potential difference, V, across the 3 μF capacitor is found by using Q=VC
24 μC=V×3 μF
giving
V=8 V

Energy stored in a capacitor

Energy transfer and work done

The energy stored by a capacitor must equal the work done to separate the charges on the two plates.
As the charge increases by an amount ΔQ, the build-up of charge opposes further movement of electrons.
Work must therefore be done to move the additional charge ΔQ from one plate onto the other.
The work done, W, to move a charge Q through a constant potential difference V is W=Q×V.
For a small increase in charge, the potential difference is nearly constant and the small amount of work done ΔW=V×ΔQ.
This is the area under a graph of potential difference against charge.

Hence, the total energy stored in a capacitor is given by

W=12QV

Since Q=VC we can substitute to give

W=12CV2 or W=12Q2C

Example

A 20 μF capacitor has a potential difference across it of 6.0 V.
What charge and energy does it store?
How would these values change if the potential difference was double to 12 V?

Charge Q=CV=20×10−6 F×6.0 V=120 μC
W=12QV=12×10×10−6 C×6.0 V=360 μJ
When the potential difference is doubled, the charge is double to 240 μC.
The energy stored is now four times greater, since both the charge and the voltage are doubled. This provides a new value of 1.44 mJ

Example

A capacitor of capacitance 470 μF is connected to a potential difference of 15 V. How much energy is stored by the capacitor?

We have values for the capacitance, C, of the capacitor and the potential difference, V.
W=12×470×10−6×152≈0.05 J

Example

A capacitor of capacitance 240 nF stores a charge of 2.3 μC. How much energy is stored in the capacitor?
W=12Q2C=12×(2.3×10−6)2240×10−9≈11 μJ

Releasing stored energy

If a capacitor is connected in series with a resistive component without a cell, the capacitor will discharge.
The direction of the current will be opposite to the direction of the current in the charging circuit.

If two capacitors are charged and then placed together in parallel, charge will flow until the potential difference across each of them is the same.
Since charge is conserved there can be no change in the amount of charge.

Example

A 8 μF capacitor is charged by a 25 V supply and is then connected in parallel to a 20 μF capacitor that has no charge on its plates. Calculate:

a) the final potential difference across each capacitor
The initial charge on the 8 μF capacitor is found by Q=25×8×10−6 =2×10−4 C.
The total capacitance of the capacitors in parallel is 28 μF.
So, the potential difference across the capacitors will also be fund from Q=VC, giving
2×10−4=V×28×10−6.
V is therefore 7.1 V.

b) the final charge stored on each capacitor
For the 8 μF capacitor we obtain Q=7.1×8×10−6=5.68×10−5 C.
For the 20 μF capacitor we obtain Q=7.1×20×10−6=1.42×10−4 C.

c) the final energy stored by each of the capacitors
For the 8 μF capacitor we obtain W=12Q2C=12×(5.7×10−55)28×10−6≈2.0×10−4 J
For the 20 μF capacitor we obtain W=12Q2C=12×(1.42×10−4)220×10−6≈5.0×10−4 J

Use of capacitors for releasing stored energy

Capacitors are not useful for large scale energy storage, as they have a relatively low capacity and also slowly discharge.
They do however have numerous applications

  • Flash devices for cameras where a high current is used to excite a gas such as xenon
  • Back up energy supplies. Large capacitors are used in back-up power supplies in data centres
  • Pulsed power in nuclear fusion research. Capacitors allow discharging large amounts of energy very quickly

Charging and discharging capacitors

Exponential decay In exponential decay, the quantity decreases at a rate which is proportional to the magnitude of the quantity at that time. x=x0e−kt

Time constant τ The time constant is the time taken for the charge remaining on a capacitor to decrease to 1e of its initial value. τ=CR

Investigation

Behaviour of p.d and current as a capacitor charges or discharges

By attaching a data logger in series, or a microammeter in series and a voltmeter across a capacitor within a charge-discharge circuit, the values of p.d and current can be measured as the capacitor charges and discharges.

Charge the capacitor, measuring the current and potential difference at fixed time intervals.
Repeat this process while discharging the capacitor.
Plot graphs of current and potential difference against time as the capacitor charges and discharges, noting similar features.
Find the times for the potential difference to fall to half of its initial value, as well as one quarter and one eighth.

Charge and discharge graphs

  • Charging current against time- Exponential decrease
  • Potential difference against time- Exponential decrease flipped in x
  • Charge on capacitor against time- Exponential decrease flipped in x

Capacitor resistor circuit

The greater the size of the resistance in the circuit, the longer the capacitor will take to become fully charged or discharged, but the final values of potential difference, charge and energy will be the same.

Exponential changes

Discharging

The charge Q, potential difference V, and current I, for a capacitor of capacitance C in a circuit of resistance R after a time t, can be expressed by the equations

Q=Q0e−tCR
V=V0e−tCR
I=I0e−tCR

where Q0 and V0 are the initial values of charge and potential difference before charging begins, and I0 is the value of current before discharging begins.

Charging

The charge Q, potential difference V, and current I, for a capacitor of capacitance C in a circuit of resistance R after a time t, can be expressed by the equations

Q=Qt(1−e−tCR)
V=Vt(1−e−tCR)
I=I0e−tCR

where Qt and Vt are respectively the final maximum charge and potential difference, and I0 is the value of current before charging before charging begins.

Graphical and spreadsheet methods

Constant ratio method

A characteristic of exponential decay of the form x=x0e−kt is that the time taken for the quantity x to fall to 1e of its initial value is a constant, k−1.
This means that equal intervals of time give equal fractional changes of 1e in x.

Logarithmic plots

Exponential decay can be rearranged by taking the natural log of each side to give

ln(x)=ln(x0)−kt

For charge in a capacitor this is ln(Q)=ln(Q0)−tCR.
This has the form y=mx+c where c is the y intercept of the slope.

Plotting ln(Q) against t we have a straight line of gradient −1CR and a y intercept of ln(Q0).

Testing the exponential decay equation

To verify that the potential difference or charge on a capacitor decreases as an exponential function.

  • Plot a graph of potential difference against time and check the time constant, or that the time to halve in value is constant
  • Plot a graph of ln(V) against t and see if it is linear

Modelling capacitor discharge

As a capacitor charges or discharges, the current I at any time is given by IVR, where V=QC.
Hence I=QRC.

For a small increase in charge, ΔQ, in a short time Δt, the current that flows is ΔQΔt.
For a discharging capacitor the charge on that capacitor decreases with time, so we can write I=−ΔQΔt.

Substituting the one equation into the other we obtain QRC=−ΔQΔt, or

ΔQΔt=−QCR

ΔQΔt can be approximated at any instant by the gradient of the curve.
Hence we can then solve for the time constant τ=RC by finding the gradient at any point.

Spreadsheet modelling

The discharge of a capacitor can be measured using an iterative method without collecting any experimental data.

To find ΔQ we divide the initial charge by RC, then multiply by the chosen time step.

ΔQ=QCR×Δt

This is the decrease in charge, so must be subtracted from the initial value of Q.

The procedure is as follows

  1. Set the initial values of C and R
  2. Enter a formula to find ΔQ
  3. Enter a formula to subtract ΔQ from the initial value of Q to get the new charge value
  4. Continue to iterate until enough data points are obtained to identify a trend

The iterative method can be expressed more succinctly as

Qt+1=Qt−Δt×QtCR

Example

A 180 μF capacitor is charged until it stores a charge of 2.4 mC.
It is then discharged through a 50 kΩ resistor.
Use an iterative method, and a time interval of 0.2 s, to find the charge remaining on the capacitor after 1.0 s.

Using CR=180×10−6 F×50×103 Ω=9 s

Time t, (s) Charge Q, (mC) ΔQΔt, (mC s−1) ΔQ, (mC) New charge, Q, (mC)
0.0 2.4 −0.27 −0.05 2.35
0.2 2.35 −0.26 −0.05 2.30
0.4 2.30 −0.26 −0.05 2.25
0.6 2.25 −0.25 −0.05 2.20
0.8 2.20 −0.24 −0.048 2.15
1.0 2.15

After 1.0 seconds, 2.15 C remains on the plates of the capacitor.

Alternatively the iterative formula can be used
Q0=2.4Q1=2.4−0.2×2.49≈2.347Q2=2.347−0.2×2.3479≈2.294Q3=22.294−0.2×2.2949≈2.244Q4=2.244−0.2×2.2449≈2.194Q5=2.194−0.2×2.1949≈2.145

Giving Q≈2.15 C after 1.0 s

Electric fields

Electric field The region around a charged body in which other charged bodies will experience a force due due to the electric charge of the body

Electric field lines Lines which show the shape of the field. The direction of a line shows the direction in which a small positive charge would move when placed at that point

Electric field strength The force per unit positive charge that a body would experience at a point in the field (N C−1)

Electric field strength

When defining electric field strength, it is the force per unit positive charge which is used.

The electric field strength E is given by
E=FQ

where F is the size of the force in newtons, and Q is the size of the positive charge in coulombs.

Example

An alpha particle of charge +3.2×10−19 C is placed at a point in an electric field where the electric field strength is 4800 N C−1.
Calculate the force that the alpha particle will experience.

From E=FQ we have F=EQ=4800×3.2×10−19≈1.5×10−15 N.

Electric field of a uniformly charged sphere

The field outside the sphere is the same as if all the charge were concentrated at a point in its centre.
The field lines are directed along a radius, and will always point away from the centre of the sphere.

Coulomb’s law

Coulomb’s law Coulomb’s law states that the electrical force, F, between two point charges is directly proportional to the product of their charges and inversely proportional to the square of their separation, r.

F=Qq4πϵ0r2

Permittivity of free space ϵ0 The permittivity of free space is a constant related to the size of the force between electric charges in free space. It has a value of 8.85×10−12 C2 m−2 N−1

Force between two point charges

For two charges, q and Q, separated by a distance r, Coulomb’s law can be written in the form

F=kQqr2

where k is a constant of proportionality.
James Clerk Maxwell related the value of k to a physical constant, the permittivity of free space ϵ0.

The relationship between k and ϵ0 is given by k=14πϵ0, and so Coulomb’s law is usually written

F=Qq4πϵ0r2

Example

Two protons, each of charge +1.6×10−19 C are separated by a distance of 20 cm.

a) What is the size of the electrostatic force that they exert on each other?
F=Qq4πϵ0r2=(1.6×10−19)24πϵ0×0.22≈5.8×10−27 N
b) How would the size of the force change if the separation remained the same, but one of the protons was replaced with an alpha particle?
The alpha particle has twice the charge of the proton.
As the force is directly proportional to the product of the charges, the force will double to a value of approximately 1.2×10−26 N.

Resultant forces

When there is more than one force on a charge, the resultant force is the vector sum of all the forces.

Example

Two identical polystyrene balls, each of mass 2.5 g, have equal positive charge q. The balls are suspended by a thing string of length 30.0 cm that makes an angle of 22∘ with the vertical.
Find the value of the charge q.

Let T be the tension in the string.
Resolving vertically:
Fg=mg=Tcos(θ), since the vertical component of the tension must balance the weight of the polystyrene ball.

This leads to
2.5×10−3×9.81=Tcos(22∘), which gives
T=2.5×10−3×9.81cos(22∘)≈0.026 N

Using the horizontal component of the forces to calculate q:
Fe=Tsin(θ)
q24πϵ0r2=Tsin(θ)
r is found by trigonometry. r=2×0.3×sin(θ).

Rearranging to make q2 the subject of the equation and substituting known values we obtain
q2=0.026×sin(22∘)×4π×8.85×10−12×(2×0.3×sin(22∘))2
giving q≈2.34×10−7 C.

This problem can also be solved from the vector triangle tan(θ)=FgFe.
